trans-unit.source: Garbage Collection ETW Events | Microsoft Docs
These events collect information pertaining to garbage collection.
They help in diagnostics and debugging, including determining how many times garbage collection was performed, how much memory was freed during garbage collection, and so on.
This category consists of the following events:
The following table shows the keyword and level.
(For more information, see [CLR ETW Keywords and Levels](../../../docs/framework/performance/clr-etw-keywords-and-levels.md).)
The following table shows the event information.
The following table shows the event data.
The generation that is being collected.
Why the garbage collection was triggered:
0x5 - Out of space (for small object heap).
0x6 - Out of space (for large object heap).
0x7 - Induced but not forced as blocking.
0x0 - Blocking garbage collection occurred outside background garbage collection.
0x2 - Blocking garbage collection occurred during background garbage collection.
Unique ID for the instance of CLR or CoreCLR.
The following table shows the keyword and level.
The following table shows the event information.
The following table shows the event data.
Unique ID for the instance of CLR or CoreCLR.
The following table shows the keyword and level.
The following table shows the event information.
Shows the heap statistics at the end of each garbage collection.
The following table shows the event data.
The size, in bytes, of generation 0 memory.
The number of bytes that are promoted from generation 0 to generation 1.
The size, in bytes, of generation 1 memory.
The number of bytes that are promoted from generation 1 to generation 2.
The size, in bytes, of generation 2 memory.
The number of bytes that survived in generation 2 after the last collection.
The size, in bytes, of the large object heap.
The number of bytes that survived in the large object heap after the last collection.
The total size, in bytes, of the objects that are ready for finalization.
The number of objects that are ready for finalization.
The number of synchronization blocks in use.
The number of garbage collection handles in use.
Unique ID for the instance of CLR or CoreCLR.
The following table shows the keyword and level.
The following table shows the event information.
A new garbage collection segment has been created.
In addition, when tracing is enabled on a process that is already running, this event is raised for each existing segment.
The following table shows the event data.
Unique ID for the instance of CLR or CoreCLR.
Note that the size of segments allocated by the garbage collector is implementation-specific and is subject to change at any time, including in periodic updates.
Your app should never make assumptions about or depend on a particular segment size, nor should it attempt to configure the amount of memory available for segment allocations.
The following table shows the keyword and level.
The following table shows the event information.
A garbage collection segment has been released.
The following table shows the event data.
Unique ID for the instance of CLR or CoreCLR.
The following table shows the keyword and level.
The following table shows the event information.
Resumption from common language runtime suspension has begun.
The following table shows the keyword and level.
The following table shows the event information.
Resumption from common language runtime suspension has ended.
The following table shows the keyword and level.
The following table shows the event information.
Start of suspension of the execution engine for garbage collection.
The following table shows the event data.
The GC count at the time.
Usually, you would see a subsequent GC Start event after this, and its Count would be this Count + 1 as we increase the GC index during a garbage collection.
Unique ID for the instance of CLR or CoreCLR.
The following table shows the keyword and level:
The following table shows the event information:
End of suspension of the execution engine for garbage collection.
The following table shows the keyword and level.
The following table shows the event information.
Each time approximately 100 KB is allocated.
The following table shows the event data.
This value is accurate for allocations that are less than the length of a ULONG (4,294,967,295 bytes).
If the allocation is greater, this field contains a truncated value.
0x0 - Small object allocation (allocation is in small object heap).
0x1 - Large object allocation (allocation is in large object heap).
Unique ID for the instance of CLR or CoreCLR.
This value is accurate for very large allocations.

When there are several types of objects that were allocated during this event, this is the address of the MethodTable that corresponds to the last object allocated (the object that caused the 100 KB threshold to be exceeded).
The name of the type that was allocated.
When there are several types of objects that were allocated during this event, this is the type of the last object allocated (the object that caused the 100 KB threshold to be exceeded).
The heap where the object was allocated.
This value is 0 (zero) when running with workstation garbage collection.
The following table shows the keyword and level.
The following table shows the event information.
The following table shows the keyword and level.
The following table shows the event information.
The following table shows the event data.
The number of finalizers that were run.
Unique ID for the instance of CLR or CoreCLR.
The following table shows the keyword and level.
The following table shows the event information.
Concurrent garbage collection thread was created.
The following table shows the keyword and level.
The following table shows the event information.
Concurrent garbage collection thread was terminated.
